ygData.subject: Re: Speciation in JNEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: Yes, that is a good point.  In fact, killing off a species is a delicate business and needs to be done carefully.  You cannot simply delete the species

Yes, that is a good point.  In fact, killing off a species is a delicate =
business and needs to be done carefully.  You cannot simply "delete" the sp=
ecies because NEAT allocates offspring based on a formula that would be una=
ware of such a deletion, which could lead to e.g. a reduction in the popula=
tion size.  By intervening at the fitness level, it is possible to leave th=
e allocation procedure alone to do its thing and rely on the fitness penalt=
y to take care of extinguishing the species.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.=
com, Daniel Tuohy <danielr2e@...> wrote:
>
> I would point out that, in JNE=
AT at least, "killing" the species just means
> adjusting the fitnesses of =
the organisms to 1% of their value and letting
> selection do as it will fr=
om there.
> 
> Daniel
> 
> On Sun, Mar 7, 2010 at 9:08 PM, Jeff Clune <jclu=
ne@...> wrote:
> 
> >
> >
> > > The dropoff_age is a way to penalize stagna=
tion. It does not kill of
> > species
> > > after e.g. 50 generations; rath=
er, it kills the species off after 50
> > > generations of *stagnation*, wh=
ich means lack of improvement in maximum
> > > fitness. The idea is, if a s=
pecies has not improved in a long time, then
> > the
> > > investment that =
it represents in CPU resources may not be worth it, so it
> > can
> > > be =
caused to die out by massively penalizing it. Of course, using this
> > > t=
echnique is optional and up to the experimenter.
> >
> > Hi Ken-
> >
> > A =
quick and minor question: out of curiosity, how does this technique
> > beh=
ave
> > if the population as a whole has stagnated for more than 50 generat=
ions
> > (which is very common at the end of long runs).
> >
> > -jeff
> >
=
> >
> > >
> > > ken
> > >
> > > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <neat%40yahoogr=
oups.com>, Daniel Tuohy
> > <danielr2e@> wrote:
> > >>
> > >> Sorry, that l=
ast message was sent prematurely. I'm still pretty
> > >> clumsy on the iPh=
one.
> > >>
> > >> I found separate speciation code in the reproduction log=
ic that
> > >> appears to be correct. My only concern, then, is the growth =
of the
> > >> number of species mentioned in the original email.
> > >>
> >=
 >> I'm also curious about the "dropoff age" feature that kills off
> > >> =
species that have been around for a certain number of generations
> > >> (d=
efault is 50). Is this a standard NEAT feature?
> > >>
> > >> Daniel
> > >>=

> > >> On Mar 7, 2010, at 2:43 PM, Daniel Tuohy <danielr2e@> wrote:
> > >>=

> > >>> After looking into this some more, I have found that there is
> > =
>>> speciation code amidst in the reproduction
> > >>>
> > >>> On Mar 6, 20=
10, at 4:16 PM, Daniel Tuohy <danielr2e@> wrote:
> > >>>
> > >>>>
> > >>>> =
Hello,
> > >>>>
> > >>>>
> > >>>> My refactoring of JNeat has brought me to=
 the speciation code, and
> > >>>> I'm finding it tricky to reconcile the J=
Neat speciation code with
> > >>>> descriptions in NEAT papers and discussi=
on in this forum. There is
> > >>>> a lot going on here, but I think I can =
state the problem simply
> > >>>> without getting into the details of the J=
Neat code.
> > >>>>
> > >>>> Ken's paper describes speciation as occuring e=
very generation.
> > >>>> Speciation entails iterating over the population,=
 and performing
> > >>>> some rudimentary clustering using a compatibility =
function and
> > >>>> threshhold. Pretty straightforward.
> > >>>>
> > >>>>=
 Indeed, this algorithm is implemented in JNeat as the speciate()
> > >>>> =
method, but its only invoked at the beginning of evolution and
> > >>>> nev=
er again! The growth and death of species afterwards is
> > >>>> determined=
 by some code in the epoch() method that does not appear
> > >>>> to resemb=
le NEAT speciation. I'm concerned that whatever JNeat is
> > >>>> doing, it=
 isn't what Ken had in mind, and it leads to some strange
> > >>>> behavior=
. Attached is a graph showing how the number of species
> > >>>> grows duri=
ng a run of the XOR experiment. With a population size
> > >>>> of 500, it =
increases almost monotonically to 400 before leveling
> > >>>> off after 40=
 generations.
> > >>>>
> > >>>> Shouldn't the speciate() method be called a=
fter ever generation/
> > >>>> epoch? Isn't this way too many species? Appr=
oximately how many
> > >>>> species would you expect for the XOR experiment=
 with 500 individuals?
> > >>>>
> > >>>>
> > >>>> Regards,
> > >>>> Daniel
